note: In Germany, cryptocurrencies are considered private assets and are subject to individual Income Tax.
Selling, swapping, or spending cryptocurrency held for less than one year is taxable if the profit exceeds €600.
Cryptocurrencies held for more than one year can be sold tax-free, regardless of the amount of profit.
Earning cryptocurrency through activities like mining or staking is considered income and is subject to Income Tax.
Purchasing and holding cryptocurrencies are not taxable events in Germany.
Gifting cryptocurrency is tax-free up to €20,000 for friends and up to €500,000 for spouses; amounts exceeding these thresholds are subject to gift tax.
Receiving airdropped cryptocurrency without providing any service in return is generally tax-free upon receipt.
Losses from cryptocurrency investments can be offset against gains, but only if both are subject to the same tax rate.
Taxpayers are required to report their cryptocurrency gains and losses in their annual tax returns, maintaining detailed records of all transactions.
The German tax authority collaborates with major cryptocurrency exchanges to share KYC data, ensuring tax compliance among investors.
The proposed EU directive, Dac8, aims to enhance data sharing, granting the German tax authority greater authority to access information on individuals' cryptocurrency holdings.
It's essential for investors to stay informed about the evolving tax regulations in Germany to ensure accurate reporting and compliance with the law.
